Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story: I sit at my desk, the soft glow of the lamp illuminating the stack of bills on one side and my open Torah on the other. My mind races with numbers—how much we owe on the home loan, how little time remains before the next payment is due. My spouse has been anxious, and I feel the weight of their worry, the expectation that I will keep our family secure, that I will not let us falter. Yet, as I glance at my notes for the Shabbat sermon, I remember the congregation’s trust in me. They look to me for guidance, for words that will uplift and inspire them each week. The service is only days away, and I have barely begun to shape my message. I know they expect my full presence, my thoughtful preparation. But every time I try to focus on the sermon, my thoughts drift back to the looming payment, the fear of letting my family down. I feel torn, pulled in two directions by love and duty, unable to give either role the attention it deserves. My heart aches as I wonder which responsibility I must set aside, even for a moment.
